texts.definition: Very large artificial objects in game worlds that provide evidence of powerful entities or groups of individuals.
markups: <style="Definition">Very large artificial objects in game worlds that provide evidence of powerful entities or groups of individuals.</style>

Games often contain big mysterious objects on a different scale than the players in their game worlds. In science fiction literature, such structures are called <style="CurrentLink">Big Dumb Objects</style>, and are used to create a sense of wonder or otherworldliness.
See also the Wikipedia entry<ref name="wiki"/> for the concept.

The majority of the gameplay in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Halo%20series">Halo series</link></style> takes place on the Ringworld-like<ref name="ringworld"/> structures the series are named after.

The White Gold Tower in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Elder%20Scrolls%20IV:%20Oblivion">The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion</link></style> dominates the Imperial City of Cyrodiil, and can be seen from long distances when players travel in the wilderness of the game world.

Introducing <style="CurrentLink">Big Dumb Objects</style> to games consist mainly of deciding who created them, what they look like, and where in the <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> they are located. As an option, <style="CurrentLink">Big Dumb Objects</style> can be so large that they are the actually <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> - the ring structures in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Halo%20series">Halo series</link></style> are examples of this.

Given their size, and typically mysterious nature, <style="CurrentLink">Big Dumb Objects</style> are <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>. While they can be designed so they can be seen from any type of location, using them so they can visible from <style="Link"><link="transport-routes">Transport Routes</link></style> can make otherwise boring movement interesting.

Given how obvious <style="CurrentLink">Big Dumb Objects</style> are, they need to be part of <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> in the form of <style="Link"><link="environmental-storytelling">Environmental Storytelling</link></style> unless they are going to quite bluntly break <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>.

As mentioned above, <style="CurrentLink">Big Dumb Objects</style> are examples of <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. There presence is often motivated by how they help maintaining a <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>. They also typically help players in performing <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style> since they provide players with a <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style> to easily recognizable <style="Link"><link="landmarks">Landmarks</link></style>. Since they are visible from long distances, they let players have the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style> of reaching them for a long time. When they cannot be reached, they instead give rise to perceivable <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>.

When the <style="CurrentLink">Big Dumb Objects</style> are introduced to <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> that otherwise are based on the real world, they do become instances of <style="Link"><link="alien-space-bats">Alien Space Bats</link></style>.
